content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Bon exercice de manipulation de chaîne de caractères, même si un peu difficile à modéliser au début

It's a good clash. 
But I think it would be better to do it in shortest mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A good CoC.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting CoC, it may be difficult to understand in reverse but otherwise it's nice

I like it. Simple, but not trivial. I think it's OK for a "reverse". However, I don't see anything fun to exploit here in the shortest mode. 

One thing that you could do, is to use palindromic phrases from more languages (instead of the random ones). Here are some in Polish: "może jutro ta dama da tortu jeżom", "kobyła ma mały bok", "łapał za kran a kanarka złapał".

It's great for shortest and fastest.
I think it's not a great candidate for a reverse challenge. I think devs would have a hard time sussing out the pattern.

Can't really know without focus testing. Unfortunately everyone who comes here will read the description first. I did use the most well known palindromes, including one in French which may actually help out the English speakers more! And with naive eyes, the pattern that sticks out to me first, apart from being a correctly constructed sentence, is that all start and end with the same letter. So it might be OK.
I'd love to use at least one, if not all 3, but I'm afraid people will complain about the non-ascii characters. Do you think it would still be recognizable in Polish, to use the z without the dot?
Are you specifically talking about the first example, or just your general experience in solving it?
